title: De Blasio flies his 'car guy' flag and enrages safe streets advocates
text:
As public advocate in 2012, Bill de Blasio called New York City’s sharp-elbowed former transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, a “radical” for her bike lane expansion program. | AP Photo De Blasio flies his 'car guy' flag and enrages safe streets advocates

Mayor Bill de Blasio let his “car guy” undercarriage show again Wednesday, when in the midst of a spike in cyclist deaths, he publicly mulled the question of helmet and license requirements for city bikers.

Both topics are third rails among cycling advocates, and neither is considered likely to happen in New York City. But de Blasio’s public dalliance with the two ideas will do little to restore faith among safe streets advocates that he has truly recommitted to driving down street fatalities, or that he understands why they argue for more protected bike lanes unobstructed by trucks or cops.

Story Continued Below

Rather, his comments are likely to reinforce the notion that beneath his Vision Zero veneer, the mayor is a “car guy” at heart.

“That’s what he is,” said Jon Orcutt, the spokesperson for Bike New York. “He doesn’t have a point of view of the city from the sidewalk or the subway or the bike lane. He’s got a point of view of it from his car. He just doesn’t get this stuff.”

De Blasio’s history on the topic is rife with comments that Orcutt and his ilk, who comprise an increasingly powerful interest group, view as rhetorical missteps that undermine his stated policy goals.

As public advocate in 2012, he called New York City’s sharp-elbowed former transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, a “radical” for her bike lane expansion program, and described himself as more of a bike lane “incrementalist.” He has since adopted, on paper, her approach to street redesign.

As mayor in 2015 he considered tearing up the Times Square pedestrian plazas beloved by urbanists the world over, only to back down under intense criticism. In 2018, he said he was open to ticketing pedestrians for walking while texting. That also came to naught.

On Wednesday, a reporter asked de Blasio if he was open to requiring helmets for users of New York City’s bikeshare program, Citi Bike.

“I have thought about that, and that’s something we’re talking about inside the administration,” he said. “There are different viewpoints on what would work and how much impact it would have. But I think it’s a real valid issue so it’s something we’re studying right now.”

When POLITICO asked for more details about those ongoing discussions, a spokesperson for the mayor referred back to his public comments.

An administration official who would normally be privy to those sorts of talks expressed surprise at the mayor’s comments.

“I don’t know of any conversations of this kind that have been going on,” the official said, requesting anonymity.

During the same press conference, another reporter asked de Blasio about requiring bikes be registered with the city, since the motor vehicles they share the road with are licensed.

He said he hadn't given the idea any thought, but that it was a "valid discussion."

"First and foremost it's about enforcement of the motor vehicles, where we still have the central problem," de Blasio said. "We are going to keep expanding enforcement on bicycles as well, because we still have a lot of bike riders who have to remember they have to follow the rules. But in terms of other things we should do, we don't have a final plan for that now, but I think all of these proposals are fair and we should look at them."

De Blasio’s comments unnerved safe streets advocates, who argue that he threatens to undermine his own cycling and safe streets programs, including his efforts to expand Citi Bike, cut cyclist deaths through the expansion of bike lanes, and fully eliminate traffic deaths through Vision Zero.

Helmet requirements have been blamed for low bike share usage in other cities and experts believe streets are safer for cyclists when there are more cyclists on streets.

Requiring Citi Bike riders wear helmets “would throw an atom bomb into the positive trajectory we’re seeing around Citi Bike ridership,” said Orcutt.

Julie Wood, a spokesperson for Citi Bike, echoed the sentiment, as did Nicole Gelinas, a transportation expert with the right-leaning Manhattan Institute.

“The helmet comments are demoralizing because it shows how hard it is to make policy progress in this city even when things are supposedly going well,” Gelinas said. “We need a complete redesign of the streets ... Instead, we’re having what seems like a sort of retro, 1990s-style debate with someone’s well-meaning but clueless relative who knows nothing about the topic of helmets.”

De Blasio’s comments about bike registration got a similar reception, particularly given the context. As of September 4, 20 cyclists have died on city streets, compared to 10 in all of 2018, according to Marco Conner, deputy director of Transportation Alternatives. This year, cyclists have killed two pedestrians, by Conner's count. On average, they kill fewer than one person a year. De Blasio's comments came following a recent New York Post story about the dangers that some cyclists pose to pedestrians.

“Just because we require licenses and training to operate a multi-ton lethal vehicle in the form of a car or truck, doesn't mean we should automatically do the same with bicycles, which do not pose the same danger even remotely,” Conner said. “And on top of that, we’ve seen from the NYPD that they are not capable of enforcing bicycling laws in a racially neutral manner."

Council Speaker Corey Johnson, who's assiduously courted the safe-streets vote for his likely mayoral bid, was none too impressed, either.

"I am all about safety, but we need to be encouraging cycling, not creating obstacles," he tweeted. "These ideas won’t help us increase bike riding in NYC."
description: Bill de Blasio's comments are likely to reinforce the notion that beneath his Vision Zero veneer, the mayor is a “car guy” at heart.
